jakartaSection.title: Let's Explore Jakarta's Icons!
jakartaSection.subtitle: Did You Know?
jakartaSection.desc: Jakarta has many iconic places like Monas and Kota Tua. Though modern, it still holds unique history and culture. Fun fact: Jakarta was originally called Batavia before becoming Indonesia’s capital.

budaya.title: Betawi Cultural Details
budaya.subtitle: Betawi culture is a heritage rich in historical values and traditions. From giant ondel-ondel dolls to the iconic kebaya house, all are symbols of Betawi people's identity. This uniqueness makes Betawi culture interesting to learn and preserve.

ondel.title: Ondel-Ondel
ondel.desc:
Ondel-ondel is a giant puppet typical of the Betawi people, used to enliven traditional ceremonies and celebrations. These puppets have striking appearances with red or white faces and stiff hair. They usually appear in pairs, male and female, accompanied by traditional music.

The presence of ondel-ondel is believed to ward off evil spirits and bring good fortune. Although the appearance has become more modern today, its cultural and spiritual meaning is still preserved by the Betawi community.

silat.title: Betawi Silat
silat.desc:
Betawi Silat is a traditional martial art developed among the Betawi people. Its fighting style is agile and strategic, combining speed, flexibility, and spirituality. It is often performed at ceremonies or cultural events.

Besides being a form of self-defense, Betawi Silat is also seen as a cultural heritage that teaches values of politeness, courage, and local wisdom. It is a symbol of strength and Betawi identity.

baju.title: Sadariah Outfit & Kebaya Encim
baju.desc:
Betawi traditional clothing reflects the cultural diversity that influences it, such as Malay, Arab, Chinese, and Dutch elements. Men usually wear sadariah shirts and caps, while women wear kebaya encim with batik cloth. The colors are bright and the design is graceful.

These traditional outfits are not only worn during cultural celebrations but also represent the pride in the identity and traditions of the open and friendly Betawi people.

rumah.title: Kebaya House
rumah.desc:
The Betawi traditional house, known as the Kebaya House, has a roof shaped like folded kebaya fabric. Another characteristic is the spacious front porch decorated with carved wooden ornaments. It is designed openly to suit Jakarta's tropical climate.

The philosophy of the Kebaya house design reflects the values of family, openness, and harmony with nature upheld by the Betawi people.

kue.title: Akar Kelapa Cake
kue.desc:
Akar Kelapa Cake is a traditional Betawi snack shaped like hanging roots. It is made from glutinous rice flour, grated coconut, sugar, and eggs, then fried until crispy. Its taste is sweet and savory, making it perfect for Eid or family gatherings.

This cake is loved not only for its taste but also for its uniqueness, which reflects the culinary creativity of the Betawi people.

jakarta.title: Jakarta Icons
jakarta.desc: Here are four iconic places that reflect the culture, history, and diversity of Jakarta.

monas.title: Monas
monas.desc: The National Monument (Monas) is a symbol of Indonesia’s independence struggle, standing tall in the heart of Jakarta. Built during President Soekarno's era, the monument is 132 meters high with a gold-plated peak. Monas offers an educational tourist experience with a historical museum at its base and panoramic city views from the top.

kotatua.title: Old Town
kotatua.desc: Jakarta's Old Town preserves Dutch colonial history with iconic old buildings such as the Fatahillah Museum and Café Batavia. This area is a popular cultural and photography destination, bringing a nostalgic atmosphere amid the city's modern bustle.

istiqlal.title: Istiqlal & Cathedral
istiqlal.desc: The Istiqlal Mosque and Jakarta Cathedral stand side by side as symbols of tolerance and interfaith harmony. Istiqlal is the largest mosque in Southeast Asia, while the Cathedral features magnificent and historic neo-Gothic architecture.

babakan.title: Setu Babakan
babakan.desc: Setu Babakan is the center of Betawi cultural village in South Jakarta. Visitors can enjoy and learn about Betawi arts, cuisine, traditional houses, and customs in a lush and natural environment.
